comment.author: 54968992@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] 
All those names are Media made not by Joe Public Carol.
I was in around the site in the days after the initial explosion as my father brought me to see (if memory serves me) to the Savoy to see 'You only Live Twice' the James Bond Movie.
We normally got the number 19 bus on the same side as the GPO up outside the C.I.E. head office, but we had to head to the Quays to get the No.34/34a.
Great shot and great to see it in colour, all I ever saw was in B&W.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: The Spike in the Dike is not a patch on Horatio Lord Nelson!  My father-in-law was in Dublin for that night and the family always accused him of being involved.  In fact he was staying not far away in Gardiner Place and never heard a thing!  That young Guard almost got into the picture but not quite!

comment.author: 8834614@N07
comment._content:
I recently  got a copy of my great grandfathers journal.  He left a small town in the western United States and was in England for around three years, much of which was during WWI  the following is a page during 1914 when he visited Nelsons pillar and other places in Dublin as well.
Monday, October 5, 1914
(notes from WWI) The Prince of Wales fund reaches 3,000,000 pounds.
I went through the Bank of Ireland. It used to be the Irish House of Parliament. I went through rooms occupied by the House of Common and House of Lords. This building was bought by the Bank of Ireland in 1799. I also went through the Dublin Castle. I seen the coat of arms of many families. Was in the room were the Crown jewels were stolen worth 50,000 pounds or $250,000 dollars. They have never been recovered. I also visited Chapel Royal which adjoins the Dublin Castle. I visited the Guiness Brewery, the largest of the kind in the world…….I also visited Phoenix Park, seen large Irish granite monument erected in honor of the Duke of Wellington……It was completed in 1861. On the sides are large tablets cast out of the guns and cannons he had captured illustrating men at war showing cannons, men and horses, etc. I also went to the top of Nelson Pillar which is located near the center of Dublin on Sackville Street.     
Note added by reddirt791 (me)  Note: (Sackville Street' was renamed in 1924 by Dublin Corporation in honor of Daniel O'Connell, to O'Connell Street). (Nelson Pillar was blown up by the IRA in 1966, the spire of light now sits on that location in the center of O’Connell Street)The population of Dublin is about 350,000 people.

comment.author: 8834614@N07
comment._content:
From the day before if you are interested.
A few days from J. O. Stone's Journal

Sunday, October 4, 1914
Arrived at Dublin about 7:30 a.m. put up at the Globe Hotel 95 Talbot Street. Went up to St. Savior's Church, also St. Georges Parish Church. Seen 800 Irish Volunteers drill and march in the streets of Dublin. Seen 26 young Catholic students (for the ministry) going to the Cathedral to meet the Arch Bishop. Seen old woman picking up the stubs of cigarettes. Seen old woman with mans coat on with gunny sack from her waist down.
Also seen little old woman leading a little dog with a green blanket on. Went out to Howth Harbor and on top of the hill of Howth and overlooked the Dublin Harbor. When I asked boys where the old Parish Church was, the first boy said Father William Church; they are all his, the second boy said yes and the graveyard is his too. I came back and attended Catholic services at Pro Cathedral. This inscription was on a brass plate in front of the seat where I sat, “Pray for the soul of Valentine Byrne who died 21st of May 1875 R.I.P.”

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/reddirt791] What a great journal and you are so lucky to have it! This is the view that your great grandfather would have had from the top of Nelson's Pillar. I wish that you were going to be in Dublin on Wednesday 21st March. We're having a WWI Roadshow day here at the library, and your great grandfather's journal would be perfect for it...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8834614@N07
comment._content: Send me a ticket and I'll be there, haha

comment.author: 8834614@N07
comment._content: My Brother and I have both spent time in Ireland, A few years apart, he in the late 70's in the North and me in the Early 80's mostly in Dublin.  At the time nether of us knew that our Great Grandfather had ever been to England or Ireland.  As it turned out we nearly walked all of his footsteps, in Dublin and Belfast.  We just found about his journal 4 years ago.  He also visited Glasneven Cemetery,  a lived in a flat just over the wall from there shortly after I arrived, as well as down the rode from Guinness on Inchicore road. Pro Cathedral was the first I visited as it was just off the stop from the Howth road Bus.  The first place I lived in Dublin.  It left me nothing short of breathless when reading it for the first time.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/reddirt791] I can imagine (the breathlessness)! Wish we could send you a ticket...  :)

comment.author: 56845705@N04
comment._content: why the Nelson's Pillar was demolished?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Who would like to field this question from [http://www.flickr.com/photos/riccardoguantini] ?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I'll give it a go and be serious in deference to Riccardo. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/riccardoguantini] In the 1950s the IRA (Irish Republican Army) continued to exist and to target the British in whatever form it might be.  They began to attack symbols of British Power such as statues, monuments and buildings.  Nelsons Pillar was the most obvious symbol in the centre of the principal street in the capital city and that was why they targeted it.  When it was damaged by the first explosion the decision was made by the government to remove the remainder and the Irish Army were brought in to demolish the base and what was left of the column.  It was a great pity as the Pillar as it was known was a great landmark and much better than its replacement.

comment.author: 8420103@N05
comment._content: Just a footnote to the comment on the army. The first explosion on 8 March did some damage in the street, but not a lot. The army explosion did a lot more. But you have to remember the first explosion was much higher up while the army's was much lower down (at the base of the column) so compression in the street was that much greater. The army did a great job. The whole thing was was very exciting. Like a night out. The remains of the pillar were floodlit and I think it was Kevin O'Kelly who did the countdown over the PA (no doubt practicing for the moon landing). There was a huge cheer when it went up - a great party atmosphere in the street. I treasure that moment.
